tn.text: Paul reminds the believers of their past and the way they now are before God.

tn.ref: you were dead in your trespasses and sins
tn.text: This shows how sinful people are unable to obey God in the same way a dead person is unable to respond physically. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The words "trespasses" and "sins" have similar meanings. Paul uses them together to emphasize the greatness of the people's sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: according to the ways of this world
tn.text: The apostles also used "world" to refer to the selfish behaviors and corrupt values of the people living in this world. AT: "according to the values of people living in the world" or "following the principles of this present world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the ruler of the authorities of the air
tn.text: This refers to the devil or Satan.
"the spirit of Satan, who is working"

tn.ref: the desires of the body and of the mind
tn.text: The words "body" and "mind" represent the entire person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
people with whom God is angry (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"God is abundant in mercy" or "God is very kind to us"

tn.ref: because of his great love with which he loved us
tn.text: "because of his great love for us" or "because he loves us very much"

tn.ref: While we were dead in trespasses, he made us alive together in Christ
tn.text: This shows how a sinful person is unable to obey God until he is given new spiritual life just like a dead person is unable to respond physically unless he is raised from the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he made us alive together in Christ
tn.text: "In Christ" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.

tn.ref: by grace you have been saved
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "God saved us because of his great kindness toward us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: God raised us up together with Christ, and God made us sit together in the heavenly places in Christ Jesus
tn.text: Just as he already raised Christ, he will raise us up too, and we will be with Christ in heaven.
"in the supernatural world." The word "heavenly" refers to the place where God is. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:eph:01:03|1:3]].

"In Christ Jesus" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.
"in the future"

tn.ref: For by grace you have been saved through faith
tn.text: God's kindness to us is the reason he made it possible for us to be saved from judgment if we simply trust in Jesus. AT: "God saved you by grace because of your faith in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "this" refers back to "by grace you have been saved by faith."
"this salvation did not come because of good things you have done"

"In Christ Jesus" and similar expressions are metaphors that frequently occur in the New Testament letters. They express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him.
"follow" or "do" (UDB)
Paul reminds these believers that God has now made Gentiles and Jews into one body through Christ and his cross.
This refers to people who were not born Jewish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Non-Jewish people were not circumcised as babies and thus the Jews considered them people who do not follow any of God's laws. AT: "uncircumcised pagans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This was another term for Jewish people because all male infants were circumcised when they were 8 days old. AT: "circumcised people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"unbelievers"

tn.ref: what is called the "circumcision" in the flesh made by human hands
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "Jews, who are circumcised by humans" or 2) "Jews, who circumcise the physical body."
This can be translated with an active form. AT: "by what people call" or "by those whom people call" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: strangers to the covenants of the promise
tn.text: Paul speaks to the Gentile believers as if they had been foreigners, kept out of the land of God's covenant and promise. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul is marking a contrast between the Ephesians before they believed in Christ and after they believed in Christ.

tn.ref: you who once were far away from God have been brought near by the blood of Christ
tn.text: Due to the believers' sins, they were separated from God. However, now Jesus has brought them near to God by his blood. AT: ]
The blood of Christ is a metonym for his death. AT: "by Christ's death" or "when Christ died for us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Jesus gives us his peace"
"He made the Jews and Gentiles one"
"By the death of his body on the cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the wall of hatred" or "the wall of ill will"
The word "us" refers to Paul and the Ephesians. The Gentiles were separated from the Jews. AT: "that separated us Jews and Gentiles from one another" (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: he abolished the law of commandments and regulations
tn.text: Jesus' blood satisfied the law of Moses so that both the Jews and Gentiles can live at peace in God.
a single new people, the people of redeemed humanity (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
It is union with Christ that makes reconciliation possible between Jews and Gentiles.
"Christ brings the Jews and the Gentiles together in peace"
The cross here represents Christ's death on the cross. AT: "by means of Christ's death on the cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Stopping their hostility is spoken of as if he killed their hostility. By dying on the cross Jesus eliminated the reason for Jews and Gentiles to be hostile toward each other. Neither are now required to live according to the law of Moses. AT: "stopping them from hating one another" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul tells the Ephesian believers that present Gentile believers are also now made one with the Jewish apostles and prophets; they are a temple for God in the Spirit.
"announced the gospel of peace" or "declared the gospel of peace"
This refers to the Gentiles or non-Jews.
This refers to the Jews.

tn.ref: For through Jesus we both have access
tn.text: Here "we both" refers to Paul, the believing Jews, and the believing non-Jews. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
All believers, both Jewish and Gentile, are given the right to enter into the presence of God the Father by the same Holy Spirit.

Paul is again speaking of the spiritual condition of Gentiles after they become believers as he would speak about foreigners becoming citizens of a different nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You have been built on the foundation
tn.text: Paul speaks of God's people as if they were a building. Christ is the cornerstone, the apostles are the foundation, and the believers are the structure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in the active tense. AT: "God has built you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the whole building fits together and grows as a temple
tn.text: Paul continues to speak of Christ's family as if it were a building. In the same way a builder fits stones together while building, so Christ is fitting us together. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: In him ... in the Lord ... in him
tn.text: "In Christ ... in the Lord Jesus ... in Christ" These metaphors express the strongest kind of relationship possible between Christ and those who believe in him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you also are being built together as a dwelling place for God in the Spirit
tn.text: This describes how believers are being put together to become a place where God will permanently live through the power of the Holy Spirit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you also are being built together
tn.text: This can be stated as active. AT: "God is also building you together" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
